values.description:
Before `ign-gazebo` 2.7, if there was an attempt to record a log file to an existing path, the path wouldn't be overwritten and instead a new directory would be created with a number appended (i.e. `/tmp/log(1)`).

`ign-gazebo` 2.7 broke that behaviour by making logs always overwrite. We're now restoring the old behaviour (probably coming up on `ign-gazebo` 2.16.0) and offering an option to overwrite. This PR makes use of the new option so SubT can continue to behave the same regardless of the `ign-gazebo` version used.

Uses these PRs:

* https://bitbucket.org/ignitionrobotics/ign-launch/pull-requests/62
* https://bitbucket.org/ignitionrobotics/ign-gazebo/pull-requests/497
values.title: Log overwrite

Markers are not supported in blueprint so unfortunately visualization is not available. I verified the generated dat file by visualizing it in gz9.

values.description:
This pull request implements the functionality to allow breadcrumb robots operate as relays. See this document for additional notes:

[https://docs.google.com/document/d/1l0pNxFUHBcm16TQu4KAbo\_QKo6JjN-ipT2nFtkEtEhA/edit?usp=sharing](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1l0pNxFUHBcm16TQu4KAbo_QKo6JjN-ipT2nFtkEtEhA/edit?usp=sharing)

This pull request will need a second part. In the second part, we’ll be notified when a breadcrumb robot has been spawned, and we’ll call the function introduced in this patch to update the communication model.

I did some testing on Gazebo 9 to verify the functionality:

**Communication range from X1 \(staging area\) without any breadcrumbs.**

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8ze6Mjd/images/2996229744-relay_0.png)
‌

**Communication range from X1 \(staging area\) with one breadcrumb at vertex** `6` **\(green intersection after the yellow segment\).**

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8ze6Mjd/images/917970074-relay_1.png)
‌

**Communication range from X1 \(staging area\) with breadcrumbs at vertices** `6` **and** `26`

**\(downslope segment after the light blue turn\).**

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8ze6Mjd/images/2305742824-relay_2.png)
‌

**Communication range from X1 \(staging area\) with breadcrumbs at vertices** `6`**,** `26` **and** `29` **\(intersection in blue color in the upper middle section from this perspective\).**

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8ze6Mjd/images/2855853023-relay_3.png)
‌
values.title: Communication support for breadcrumbs

values.description:
This pull request adds the missing functionality so that breadcrumbs can be deployed and work as network relays. In particular:

1. Adds the ability to deploy up to 3 breadcrumbs in X1 and X2 \(3 bcs/robot\).
2. Updates the visibility information when a new breadcrumb is deployed.

How to test it:

1 . Launch a cave environment:

```
ign launch -v 4 cave_circuit.ign worldName:=simple_cave_01 robotName1:=X1 robotConfig1:=X1_SENSOR_CONFIG_1
```

2a . Deploy a robot using Ignition: You need to publish an `ignition::msg::Empty` message on topic `/model/X1/breadcrumb/deploy` ~~If I remember correctly is not possible to use~~ `ign` ~~to publish an empty message. What I do for testing is to modify the~~ `publisher` ~~example in Ignition Transport. See the updated version~~ [~~here~~](https://pastebin.com/yS6s1gPL)~~.~~

```
ign topic -t "/model/X1/breadcrumb/deploy" -m ignition.msgs.Empty -p "unused: true"
```

2b. Deploy a robot using ROS: You need to publish an `std_msgs/Empty` message on topic `/X1/breadcrumb/deploy` :

```
rostopic pub /X1/breadcrumb/deploy std_msgs/Empty "{}" --once
```

‌

3\. After publishing the message you should see a message like this

```
[Msg] Deploying X1__breadcrumb___0 at 2.8 5 0.13228 0 0 0
[Msg] New breadcrumb detected, visibility graph updated
```

And a new breadcrumb should appear in simulation. Breadcrumbs are represented as small orange models. If you look at the entity tree, you should also see the new breadcrumb with name <robot\_name>\_\_breadcrumb\_\_<breadcrumb\_number>.E.g.: `X1__breadcrumb__0`.

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8ze6Mjd/images/2597955784-breadcrum.png)
‌

The [API](#!/osrf/subt/wiki/api) has been updated in the wiki to capture how breadcrumb works.

Note: A nicer version of the breadcrumb model is ready. I just need to upload it to Fuel.
values.title: Communication support for breadcrumbs - part 2

summary.html:
This pull request adds the missing functionality so that breadcrumbs can be deployed and work as network relays. In particular:

  1. Adds the ability to deploy up to 3 breadcrumbs in X1 and X2 (3 bcs/robot).
  2. Updates the visibility information when a new breadcrumb is deployed.

How to test it:

1 . Launch a cave environment:

ign launch -v 4 cave_circuit.ign worldName:=simple_cave_01 robotName1:=X1 robotConfig1:=X1_SENSOR_CONFIG_1

2a . Deploy a robot using Ignition: You need to publish an ignition::msg::Empty message on topic /model/X1/breadcrumb/deploy If I remember correctly is not possible to use ign to publish an empty message. What I do for testing is to modify the publisher example in Ignition Transport. See the updated version here.

ign topic -t "/model/X1/breadcrumb/deploy" -m ignition.msgs.Empty -p "unused: true"

2b. Deploy a robot using ROS: You need to publish an std_msgs/Empty message on topic /X1/breadcrumb/deploy :

rostopic pub /X1/breadcrumb/deploy std_msgs/Empty "{}" --once

‌

3. After publishing the message you should see a message like this

[Msg] Deploying X1__breadcrumb___0 at 2.8 5 0.13228 0 0 0
[Msg] New breadcrumb detected, visibility graph updated

And a new breadcrumb should appear in simulation. Breadcrumbs are represented as small orange models. If you look at the entity tree, you should also see the new breadcrumb with name <robot_name>__breadcrumb__<breadcrumb_number>.E.g.: X1__breadcrumb__0.

‌

The API has been updated in the wiki to capture how breadcrumb works.

Note: A nicer version of the breadcrumb model is ready. I just need to upload it to Fuel.

values.description: ``` # Robotika - Freyja This specifications.md file is a description and proof of virtual model validation for Robotika's robot Freyja with Sensor Configuration 1. This robot may be launched using a `roslaunch` command with the variable name `robotika_freyja_sensor_config_1`. ## Description Freyja is a four-wheel all-terrain ground vehicle. With weight under 30 kg and its medium size, Freyja can be transported by a single person as a check-in baggage on an airplane. ## Cost and Scale Robotika's Freyja has an estimated commercial cost of USD 7,000. It weighs approximately 29.6 kg. ## Sensors Freyja in Sensor Configuration 1 is equipped with forward-looking and backward looking medium-fps RGB & Depth cameras with wide field of view (Mynte Eye D), four even wider-field-of-view color cameras looking all around (KAYETON), two planar lidars (SICK TIM881P), and with other sensors, such as imu combined with a magnetic compass (CMPS14), an altimeter (Infineon DPS310), a CO2 sensor (MH-Z19B) and in-wheel encoders. The specifications for these instruments are provided below in the [Validation Links](#validation_links) section. summary.html:
# Robotika - Freyja
This specifications.md file is a description and proof of virtual model validation for
Robotika's robot Freyja with Sensor Configuration 1. This robot may be launched using
a `roslaunch` command with the variable name `robotika_freyja_sensor_config_1`.
## Description
Freyja is a four-wheel all-terrain ground vehicle. With weight under 30 kg and its
medium size, Freyja can be transported by a single person as a check-in baggage on an
airplane.

## Cost and Scale
Robotika's Freyja has an estimated commercial cost of USD 7,000. It weighs approximately
29.6  kg.

## Sensors
Freyja in Sensor Configuration 1 is equipped with forward-looking and backward looking
medium-fps RGB & Depth cameras with wide field of view (Mynte Eye D), four even
wider-field-of-view color cameras looking all around (KAYETON), two planar lidars
(SICK TIM881P), and with other sensors, such as imu combined with a magnetic compass
(CMPS14), an altimeter (Infineon DPS310), a CO2 sensor (MH-Z19B) and in-wheel encoders.

The specifications for these instruments are provided below in
the [Validation Links](#validation_links) section.

The following specific sensors are declared payloads of this vehicle:

* 2x RGBD camera — Mynt Eye D, modeled by `rgbd_camera` plugin.
* 2x Planar lidar — SICK TIM881P, modeled by `gpu_lidar` plugin.
* 4x Monocular camera — KAYETON, modeled by `camera` plugin.
* Tilt-compensated compass — CMPS14, modeled by `imu` and `magnetometer`
plugins.
* Altimeter — Infineon DPS310, modeled by `air_pressure` plugin.
* Wheel odometry - wheel encoders modelled by `pose-publisher`
plugin.
* Gas sensor — Winsen MH-Z19B, modeled by GasEmitterDetector plugin.
## Control
Freyja is controlled by the open-source Osgar framework or by custom Erro framework.
## Motion Characteristics
Based on the tests specified in the DARPA SubT Challenge [Model Preparation
Guide](https://subtchallenge.com/\<fix_me\>), this vehicle has the following motion
constraint characteristics:

* _x_ velocity range from -2.5 m/s to 2.5 m/s
* _x_ acceleration range from -10.6 m/s<sup>2</sup> to 10.6 m/s<sup>2</sup>
* Turning radius of 0.0 m

The constraints can be found in the following locations within the simulation model
package:

* Front left wheel maximum velocity and torque — model.sdf, lines 1415 and 1417
* Other wheels — just below Front Left wheel in the same file.

## Endurance Characteristics
Based on the tests specified in the DARPA SubT Challenge [Model Preparation
Guide](https://subtchallenge.com/\<fix_me\>), this vehicle has the following
endurance characteristics:

* Battery life of 14400 seconds

## Diversions from Physical Hardware of Freyja
Virtual Freyja is a faithful representation of real-world Freya both in appereance and
in physical properties.

# <a name="validation_links"></a>Freyja Validation and Specification Links

* https://www.uumotor.com/10-inch-single-shaft-brushless-motor-sensorless.html
* https://www.robot-electronics.co.uk/cmps14-tilt-compensated-compass.html
* Nearest public documentation to TIM881P: https://www.sick.com/ch/en/detection-and-ranging-solutions/2d-lidar-sensors/tim5xx/tim581-2050101/p/p619344
* https://www.kayetoncctv.com/global-shutter-high-speed-120fps-hd-720p-webcam-uvc-plug-play-driverless-usb-camera-module-for-android-linux-windows-mac/
* https://www.infineon.com/cms/en/product/sensor/pressure-sensors/absolute-pressure-sensors-map-bap/dps310/
* https://www.winsen-sensor.com/sensors/co2-sensor/mh-z19b.html
* https://youtu.be/cHJ-ZloPmhE (speed test)
* https://youtu.be/bZ83Zneuhf8 (rotation test)
* https://drive.google.com/drive/folders/1M8W3vjP1G0Pz7oeB7dAkBjXhYE05hvxA?usp=sharing

values.description:
CU's husky config with 3 D435i RGBD cameras, a pan-tilt turret, the Ouster OS1 64 channel lidar, and an RPLidar S1. We have added a pan/tilt capability and mounted one of the rgbd cameras on a gimble.

Additional details are included in the specifications.md file.

NOTE: you must build the custom ros-ign as described in BuildingCustomRosIgnForMarble.txt to run this model.

‌

* testing to see if I brett can commit a dummy file
* Made marble folder
* test commit
* Close branch submitted\_models/marble\_husky\_sensor\_config\_1.
* Added files for husky. Name will need to be changed
* Downward facing facing is there
* Got all sensor positioned and represented visually up to the pan tilt tower. That comes next
* Model sdf now has the gimbal pan, still unsure of how to control it though
* Until the joints can be tested this is where the marble hsuky model will get
* Got the joint state controller and publisher added in. Pan/Tilt can be controlled using ignition messages.
* More works needs to be done on bridges to control gimbal, but commented out in progress work is available in vehicle\_topics.launch for the marble husky
* Rudimentary visuals done
* We can now command the gimbal pan/tilt using ros topics as long as you use the modified version of ros\_ign\_bridge committed under pull request 64
* Fixed the joint publisher. Topic shows up in ros as /<vehicle name>/joint\_state.
* Update sdf file, add test\_gimbal script, add specifications.md file, and remove CU\_MARBLE folder
* Added the xacro file for rviz
* added a file
* Updated sensor description in package.xml
* Updated IMU model to Microstrain 3DM-GX5-25 as in HD2. Added link to datasheet for IMU in specifications.md file
* Add pan and tilt echoing scripts
* Updated and completed specifications.md file for husky
* Couple of edits to description files.
* Update cost info in specs.

‌

values.description:
Note: This model requires a custom ros\_ign\_bridge to be built \(or our latest PR for ros\_ign\_bridge to be incorporated\). Instructions for where to find the source code can be found in “submitted\_models/marble\_hd2\_sensor\_config\_1/BuildingCustomRosIgnBridgeForMarble.txt”

See [specifications.md](http://specifications.md) file for more information

Sensors:

* camera\_front \(based on Intel RealSense D435\)

    * 1280 x 720 resolution
    * Depth range of 10m to 0.1m
    * 30 fps
    * 86 degree Horizontal FOV and 57 degree vertical FOV
    * Topics: vehicle\_name/front\_facing/image\_raw & vehicle\_name/front\_facing/depth & vehicle\_name/front\_facing\_rgbd\_camera/depth/points & vehicle\_name/front\_facing/etc…
    
* camera\_down \(based on Intel RealSense D435\)

    * Same specifications as camera\_front
    * Topics: vehicle\_name/front\_down/image\_raw & vehicle\_name/front\_down/depth & vehicle\_name/front\_down\_rgbd\_camera/depth/points & vehicle\_name/front\_down/etc…
    
* camera\_pan\_tilt \(based on Intel RealSense D435\)

    * Same specifications as camera\_front and camera\_down
    * Topics: vehicle\_name/pan\_tilt/image\_raw & vehicle\_name/pan\_tilt/depth & vehicle\_name/pan\_tilt\_rgbd\_camera/depth/points & vehicle\_name/pan\_tilt/etc…
    
* planar\_laser \(Based off RPLidar S1\)

    * 10 hz
    * 920 horizontal samples
    * 360 degree horizontal range
    * 0.04m to 25m range
    * 3cm resolution
    * Topics: vehicle\_name/planar\_laser\_scan
    
* front\_laser \(Based off OS1-64 Laser in 20x1024 configuration\)

    * 1024 horizontal samples
    * 360 degree horizontal range
    * 64 vertical samples
    * 45 degree vertical range
    * 0.09m to 120m range
    * 1cm resolution
    * Topics: vehicle\_name/points
    
* IMU \(Based off Lord Microstrain 3DM-GX5-25 IMU\)

    * `https://www.microstrain.com/sites/default/files/applications/files/3dm-gx5-25_datasheet_8400-0093_rev_n.pdf`
    
* Pan-Tilt Gimbal

    * Pan range: -180 to 180 degrees
    * Tilt Range: -160 to 160 degrees
    * Topics: vehicle\_name/pan\_tilt/pan\_rate\_cmd\_double & vehicle\_name/pan\_tilt/tilt\_rate\_cmd\_double
    

‌

values.description:
This air vehicle is based on the qav500 vehicle fielded by the CU team.

Sensor suite includes 1 forward facing realsense d435i and 2 pico flexx depth cameras [https://pmdtec.com/picofamily/flexx/](https://pmdtec.com/picofamily/flexx/) these sensors publish both a depth image and point clouds. To accomplish this, they are modeled as rgbd cameras in the sdf file, but only point clouds and depth images are published. Please advise if this is possible with the depth\_camera sensor type in the sdf file.

There is no light currently on the physical vehicle built by CU because it has not been necessary in the tunnel environments, but one was included here for simulation purposes

The motors for the quadrotor use the same motor model as the X4 vehicle with modifications to allow for 4 motors instead of 6. The motors on the physical vehicle are Tiger MN3510 motors [http://store-en.tmotor.com/goods.php?id=337](http://store-en.tmotor.com/goods.php?id=337)

Additional details are included in the specifications.md file

* issue #353 - To reproduce: just launch a robot with rgbd camera, e.g. X3 sensor config 4 

The warnings are from compressed depth and theora topics so filtering them out from the bridge logger prevents the console from being flooded with these warning msgs.

It does not solve the underlying problem with these topics though. The bridge logger may just have helped uncover this issue, e.g. doing a `rostopic echo` also causes these warning msgs to be printed, e.g. `rostopic echo /X3/front/depth/compressed`
values.title: Disable loggin of compressed and theora topics bridge logger to fix warnings

values.description:
This PR turns on ROS topic statistics and runs a node that logs its output to `~/.ros/rostopic_stats_logger.log`:

[http://wiki.ros.org/Topics#Topic\_statistics](http://wiki.ros.org/Topics#Topic_statistics)

Example output:

```
---
topic: "/X1/pose"
node_pub: "/X1/ros_ign_bridge_pose"
node_sub: "/X1/pose_tf_broadcaster"
window_start: 
  secs: 8
  nsecs:  52000000
window_stop: 
  secs: 18
  nsecs: 512000000
delivered_msgs: 19499
dropped_msgs: 10
traffic: 1932310
period_mean: 
  secs: 0
  nsecs:    536465
period_stddev: 
  secs: 0
  nsecs:  31457921
period_max: 
  secs: 4
  nsecs: 352000000
stamp_age_mean: 
  secs: -1
  nsecs: 595962665
stamp_age_stddev: 
  secs: 0
  nsecs: 713605161
stamp_age_max: 
  secs: 1
  nsecs: 756000000
---
```

The `dropped_msgs` field could be useful. So far in my local testing, I have not seen dropped msgs for sensor topics yet but I do see many dropped msgs for the `/pose` \(consumed by `tf_broadcaster`\) and `/cmd_vel` topics

values.description:
This Pull Request submits the CERBERUS ANYmal Sensor Configuration 1 robot.

‌

The following packages are added:

* **cerberus\_anymal\_sensor\_config\_1:** this package contains the robot’s sdf model and the needed launch files for the simulation. The package moreover contains a Readme file as well as the requested [specification.md](http://specification.md) file, which contains the instructions needed to use this vehicle
* **cerberus\_anymal\_ignition\_gazebo\_plugin:** this package contains an ignition gazebo plugin needed to simulate and control the 12 actuators that enable the robot to move. This plugin is released as `.so` file.

‌

Please note that, as stated in `cerberus_anymal_sensor_config_1/specifications.md`, another repository must be used to control the robot, given an input twist to follow. This repository is publicly available on the GitHub page of our lab: [cerberus\_anymal\_locomotion](https://github.com/leggedrobotics/cerberus_anymal_locomotion) and it contains all the needed instructions.

‌

The last point worth to mention here is the decision to temporary comment out the “battery” plugin in the file `cerberus_anymal_sensor_config_1/launch/spawner.rb`. This is due to an unexpected behavior of this plugin, which freezes all the joints and does not enable to command a desired torque. We opened and [issue](https://bitbucket.org/ignitionrobotics/ign-gazebo/issues/55/battery-plugin-freezes-joints) about this problem and will enable the plugin again when the it will be fixed.
values.title: Model submission for CERBERUS ANYmal sensor configuration 1 from RSL-ETH Zurich

summary.html:
This Pull Request submits the CERBERUS ANYmal Sensor Configuration 1 robot.

‌

The following packages are added:

  • cerberus_anymal_sensor_config_1: this package contains the robot’s sdf model and the needed launch files for the simulation. The package moreover contains a Readme file as well as the requested specification.md file, which contains the instructions needed to use this vehicle
  • cerberus_anymal_ignition_gazebo_plugin: this package contains an ignition gazebo plugin needed to simulate and control the 12 actuators that enable the robot to move. This plugin is released as .so file.

‌

Please note that, as stated in cerberus_anymal_sensor_config_1/specifications.md, another repository must be used to control the robot, given an input twist to follow. This repository is publicly available on the GitHub page of our lab: cerberus_anymal_locomotion and it contains all the needed instructions.

‌

The last point worth to mention here is the decision to temporary comment out the “battery” plugin in the file cerberus_anymal_sensor_config_1/launch/spawner.rb. This is due to an unexpected behavior of this plugin, which freezes all the joints and does not enable to command a desired torque. We opened and issue about this problem and will enable the plugin again when the it will be fixed.

values.description:
installs and runs `atop` for process monitoring

By default, `atop` logs data at 10 seconds interval. A quick 10min test shows a log size of ~3.5MB. So assuming a run goes for 3hrs then we get ~63MB of log data. The interval can up configured if needed.

to read the log data, run `atop -r path_to_log_dir/atop_log`, and press `t` or `T` to go forward and back in time.

values.description:
added `dot_generator` executable that parses an sdf world file and prints out a dot graph

The code does manual string parsing as opposed to using the sdformat parser mainly because it needs the tile URI string which does not seem to be accessible through the sdformat parser. So one limitation to keep in mind is that it does filter out `<include>` blocks that are commented out, i.e. it sees them as another model that’s included.

It also reuses part of the connection validator code for identifying valid connections .

example usage:

```
$ <path_to_subt_install_dir>/share/subt_ign/dot_generator simple_cave_01.sdf > simple_cave_01.dot
```

‌
